A security assessment plan has been created to describe all security measures at this facility, identify any vulnerable areas and then document the measures taken to address those risks.  The plan is intended to work in conjunction with the Emergency Action and Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasures Plan to meet all required criteria.

Training is performed with all employees annually and within 90 days of employment.  Employees do not work in covered areas unattended until training has been completed.

ificant accident within the last five years for one or more of the regulated substances from a covered process. 

In the event of a small, controlled leak or defective valve, employees are instructed to shut down the transfer process and, if possible, don the appropriate PPE, approach the shutoff valve from upwind and attempt to turn it off. 

For an uncontainable release, employees will immediately call the police and fire department or other first responders, as appropriate.  All employees, customers and contractors are to be evacuated to an upwind location. Once the response team has arrived, we will work in concert with them to close the valves between the tank and the leak. Active response measures will include ignition control.

The employees are instructed to make emergency phone calls in this order:  911, the Facility Manager, the site and business EHS support, the state emergency hotline and the National Spill Response Center phone number.  All applicable contact names and numbers are found in the facility spill and emergency action plan. 

Communication procedures with responders 
The local fire department is invited to tour the facility on an annual basis.  Facility management, employees and fire department personnel have jointly discussed the location of the flammable liquid process, storage areas, and response procedures on a regular basis.  They know the location of all emergency shutoff valves and on-site response equipment.  We believe that a strong relationship with first responders is our best defense.

The LEPC and state regulatory agencies receive a copy of our hazardous materials storage information annually, in accordance with our community right to know obligations, to help facilitate coordinating emergency response planning involving materials at our facility.

Security Plans
The Department of Transportation (DOT), Research and Special Programs Administration (RSPA) 49 CFR Part 172, requires all facilities that offer or transport hazardous ma

s in place for hazard assessment and mitigation.  

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) has been performed at this facility, as part of the Process Safety Management Program.  The analysis will be updated every five years, or as changes in the process are made.  PHAs are performed using the What-If/Checklist protocol and analyze all aspects involved in the production of ethanol.  The evaluation team includes representatives from the business EHS support, facility Management and Operations employees.

Standard operating procedures have been established for all activities related to the natural gasoline storage and handling.  These procedures are reviewed annually by employees and management to ensure they are current.  The procedures are available to the employees at the facility in hard copy and in an electronic database. 

Formal investigations are performed for all environmental or safety incidents.  Documentation is kept on file at the facility and in the electronic incident management system.

A formal Management of Change (MOC) system is in place at this facility.  An electronic form is submitted whenever a change is made to any of the processes within the scope of the PSM program.  This ensures that appropriate documentation such as P&IDs, operating procedures, maintenance items, etc. are reviewed and updated as needed where affected by the change.  Forms are routed to the facility operator to the Engineering and business EHS support for review and remarks.  Where changes affect operating procedures, revisions are made and employee training is completed prior to start-up of the changed process.  A copy of the completed form is kept on file at the facility.   

Monthly Safety Committee meetings allow employees to discuss any concerns they may have with the operation of the facility.  Issues are documented and assigned to employees for follow-up. Records of all meetings are kept at the facility.

Response Action in the Event of a Release
The site has not had a sign

ll times.  All of the fire hydrants(s) around the tank farm are equipped with water cannons to allow for fire suppression/control from a safe distance. 

Prevention Program

Preventive maintenance is an integral piece of this facilitys hazard management program.  All hoses, tanks, valves and storage units are inspected at least monthly.  A good PM program is our strongest defense against a release of anhydrous ammonia.  All hose replacements are documented.  Records of all maintenance tasks performed on the tank or appendages are also on file.

This facility uses a certified third-party contractor for all welding and construction performed on the anhydrous ammonia tank or transfer pipes.  Copies of all reports are on file. The ammonia system undergoes a thorough inspection by a third party at least every five years.

See Steps Taken to Address Hazards for more information on prevention measures and identification.

Five Year Accident History 
The site has not had a release involving natural gasoline in the last five years.

Management System
(see Steps Taken to Address Hazards)

Equipment maintenance
All equipment maintenance is formally documented. See the Prevention Program section for further explanation.

Training
All employees receive annual training on flammable liquids, emergency action plan and spill procedures, and hazard communication.  Documentation and attendance rosters are on file at the facility.  

Contractors
Contractors that are hired by The Andersons Marathon Holdings LLC may go through a documented Prequalification process.  Records of this evaluation are kept on file.

All contractors also receive a contractor safety review prior to performing work at the facility.  During this review, they are informed of any potential hazards at the facility, emergency procedures, site-specific safety rules and the ability to request an SDS for any product at any time.

Steps Taken to Address Hazards

Natural Gasoline (Denaturant) is stored outside in a 188,000 gallon storage tank on the north end of the property in the Tank Farm.  Maximum capacity of the storage tank is 188,000 gallons.

Summary of Release Scenarios

Worst Case Release

Natural Gasoline:
The worst case release scenario would be a total loss of a full tank of natural gasoline resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The storage tank capacity is 188,000 gallons or 1,034,000 pounds.  Of the 1,034,000 pounds, about 705,705 pounds are made up of the materials subject to the Risk Management Plan.

Alternative Release

Natural Gasoline:
The most likely cause of a natural gasoline is a release during a delivery due to a faulty hose or valve resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  Deliveries are most often made by tank truck and less frequently by railcar and pumped into the storage tank.  The alternative scenario uses railcar as it involves the largest quantity.  Deliveries by rail are typically 30,000 gallons or 166,000 pounds of which 111,375 pounds are made up of the materials subject to the Risk Management Plan.

Unloading of denaturant railcars occurs during business hours and is observed by facility personnel.  If a release were to occur the attendants could stop the flow within minutes.  The loadout area where deliveries occur has a catchment basin with underground piping to secondary containment. 

Explanation on prevention of Natural Gasoline releases:

Passive Mitigation
The natural gasoline storage and unloading are equipped with secondary containment (Tank Farm).  Material release from unloading or tank farm will stay in the secondary containment.  Electrical equipment in the tank farm area is rated for Class 1 Division 1 to prevent any leakage from being ignited by electrical equipment.

Active Mitigation
Hot work in the unloading area and tank farm is strictly controlled by hot work permits.  Unloading operations are attended at a

f ethanol.  200-proof ethanol is pumped to bulk storage prior to blending with denaturant and stored in one of three Denatured Ethanol Storage Tanks.  Denaturant Ethanol Storage Tanks pump directly to loadout racks for both trucks and railcars. 

Non-fermentable corn solids and water separated from the Beer Mash or Whole Stillage is sent through a high velocity separation process, resulting in Wet Distillers Grain with Solubles (WDGS), Thin Stillage (water with solubles) and eventually Corn Oil.  Wet Distillers Grain with Solubles has a moisture content of approximately 65% and can be sold directly as animal feed prior to being further processed and dried into Dry Distillers Grain with Solubles (DDGS).  Dry Distillers Grain with Solubles has a moisture content of approximately 12% and stored on-site in a storage barn prior to loading into trucks and railcars.  The resulting recycled water or Thin Stillage is reused within the process as make-up water with solubles.  Corn Oil is a liquid co-product extracted from the Thin Stillage as a fatty-acid feedstock or biodiesel feedstock. 

Thermal Oxidizers serve as the emission control units for four Dryers as well as various process vents.  The Thermal Oxidizers are very efficient at controlling particulates, carbon monoxide, VOCs, HAPs and nuisance odors.

The facility also has a Cooling Tower for non-contact cooling water used in the Fermentation process and Distillation, and fire pump for emergency events.

RMP Applicability & Chemical Description

The chemical that requires participation in the Risk Management Plan is natural gasoline. Natural gasoline is used to denature the ethanol. Natural gasoline is a flammable mixture. There are multiple constituents of natural gasoline however, based on SDS analysis, four of those constituents, butane, pentane, isobutane, and iso-pentane or 2-methylbutane are subject to the Risk Management Plan. The Andersons Marathon Holding LLC
Greenville Operations
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Site and Process Description

The Andersons Marathon Holdings LLC is located at 5728 Sebring Warner Road, located north of Sebring Warner Rd in the City of Greenville in Darke County, Ohio.  The facility operates 24 hours a day and 7 days a week with a staff of approximately 63 people.

The following operations are performed at this facility: Grain Receiving, Drying and Storage, Grain Milling, Fermentation, Distilling, Dehydration and Evaporation, Decanter Separation, Corn Oil Extraction, Wet and Dry Distillers Grain with Solubles (WDGS / DDGS) Drying, Wet and Dry Distillers Grain with Solubles Storage and Shipping, and Ethanol Storage and Shipping.  

Corn is stored temporarily in concrete silos and steel bins prior to being fed to four Hammer Mills where the corn is dry-milled into a powder and then conveyed to the production area.

Corn is blended with water and enzymes and pumped into Fermenters for batch fermentation.  Fermentation final product results in a Beer Mash, a mixture of ethanol, non-fermentable solids, and water.  The Beer Mash product goes through a degassing process to remove residual volatile organics from fermentation, and then enters the distilling process.

CO2 gas is a byproduct of fermentation and sent to a scrubbing process that reduces the amount of ethanol and hazardous air pollutants released to the atmosphere.  A blend of water with and chemical additive flows countercurrent to the gases and removes the ethanol and HAPs from the CO2 gas.  CO2 gases from the Scrubber system vent to atmosphere or a dry ice production facility adjacent to property.

The distilling process separates components of the Beer Mash that results in 190-proof ethanol, non-fermentable solids and water.  The 190-proof ethanol is pumped to bulk storage prior to pumping into a dehydration process to remove the residual water, with the final product resulting in 200-proo
